Title: Scales and Modes around the World

Players exhibit octave?: +ACI-Many scales were omitted that were identical to those in Ref +AFs-1+AF0-. There is a chapter devoted to ancient Greek scales. There is a lot of information here
Notes on octave equivalence: but I decided that the previous inclusion of diatonic modes is sufficient. It might be worthwhile going back over this some day to include all of the hyper+AC0- and hypo+AC0- versions of the modes
Tuning octaves?: where alternative types of pythagorean tunings are used. After reading the sources in the bibliography (see David Monroe
Note name octaves?: The Modes of Ancient Greek Music)
Parallel octaves?: it seems that I am right to be skeptical +IBM- the use of this extended set of modes seems to be hypothetical. I also do not include the section on modes where the author seems to simply be enumerating circular permutants of scales. Reports of scales in Western staff notation are ignored if there is no tuning system specified. Sometimes there were extensions of Turkish scales above and below the octave +IBM- these were only included as new scales if there were differences between the notes in the upper and lower octaves. Many of the Turkish scales were duplicates
Other Notes: and occasionally the information was confusing. It would be good to eventually get a better source for these.+ACI-

Reference+AF8-Full: +ACI-A. Tracey. The nyanga panpipe dance. Afr. Music
column15: +ACI-'In common with other reedpipe dances that have been described
column16: the maker does not tune according to an abstracted scale. He does not tune each note in turn up or down the scale
column17: and he does not specifically tune together the same notes on different panpipes
column18: or check octaves or fifths. The only method seems to be to play the actual music that belongs to it
column19: on a set that is to be tuned
column20: and see if it fits with what is expected. Then two different panpipes of a similar pitch range are tested together
column21: and so on through the set. For testing any particular panpipe
column22: the one most often chosen to play against it is the one that stands next to it during the dance.'+ACI-
